reviewText:
Spectraball is an impressive 3D version of the old 'Marble Madness' style of time based skill tester game. Guide your Spectraball through the maze as fast as you can trying to avoid the traps.

Controls are easy enough, but does take some practice to move & rotate camera together. I liked the level designs, each being very uniquely themed & scaling in complexity (although there are not many to choose from making it relatively short game). There are some challenging sections which need precise control of your ball, which I found myself dieing over & over. This wasn't overly frustrating as resetting is friendly.

I felt a sense of accomplishment when I figured the next step out sometimes as there are some areas you need to stop, look & discover what's next - its not always obvious or easy on later levels. So it may be relatively short, but the what you get in the content is good.

In 2012/13 the game got complete engine overhaul, now called the 'Extended Edition', including some additional content - now less buggy & it looks great! Awesome little game for the price! Not too many like it.

Found this video on the community hub that had some good gameplay in it if you want to see more (straight gameplay so may contain spoilers):
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=194797951 (Gameplay footage uploaded by WizFish)


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
It's not a great game. Everything is kinda mediocre, and there is a fair share of bugs, but it has its moments and I still had a lot of fun. I feel like I've been missing out all these years.

This is not a puzzle game, which is OK. The buttons add minimal depth; they just move or explode something to let you proceed. Thinking is limited to figuring out where to go, which can be frustrating but sometimes also fun.

Movement is also as simple as it gets. But it's all about the environments. There is a lot of variety and many interesting parts that require much attention to the execution.

I think this is the perfect game to practice the Steam Controller (mainly controlling camera).

★★★★★★★☆☆☆

reviewText:
Awesome game!!! I would recommend this game to anyone who like challenges. It can be unforgiving at times but rewarding in return. I love the idea and concept of this game as I hope later on down the track there will be a DLC for more levels and other Mini Games for this, also maybe some extra mods for the ball other than the 3 that came with the game you have too unlock.
The game is challenging either way when using K/B & Mouse or XBOX 360 Controller, but can be played smoothly depending on what works for you.
Overall gameplay, graphics and music I am very content with what they have done. Shame the game has only 7 levels.
Graphics can be distracting and sometimes awkward when you have to move or view around to see where you have to go as objects sometimes block your vision.

Couple of minor glitches I had found while playing this game:
Random points through out the game the ball may either get stuck in corners or wedges.
Sometimes when jumping it doesnt always do it then and there. (Very rarely on odd occassions)
lvl 6 The TNT boxes sometimes get stuck and dont drop when needed too.
lvl 7 The last jump at the end you sometimes get stuck in free fall and forced to restart from the last checkpoint.

With only those minor glitches I have found, I still enjoyed playing this game and will enjoy playing it over again.
Personal rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Short Verdict: Another game I'd rate neutrally if I could. Some levels are very frustrating, but you could still have some fun for a short while. If you already have it, you might as well try it. If you don't, don't bother.

Overview: Spectraball is about rolling a ball through levels, managing speed, jumping around, taking physics into consideration and solving puzzles. Basically, it's a brainless platformer with a few puzzle elements.

Pros:
Beautiful landscapes
The overall experience provides some fun
Unlockable items and skins for your ball sphere
Cons:
Textures and graphics, when seen in detail (and not as a whole), leave much to be desired (but, to be fair, the game is from 2008)
Poorly positioned checkpoints make the game a bit more frustrating than it should be
The camera - oh, God, the camera! - sucks and it's one of the hardest aspects in the game
A bit on the short side
Controls sometimes feel a bit unnatural--at least when you're in the air, camera positioning affects the 3D movement, making some jumps harder than they should be
Puzzles seemed uninspired and are either too easy, or really frustrating because of either the camera or the controls
Extra minigames are boring and bland, not to mention the lack of BGM while you play them
Bought on: Steam Auction for 1400 gems. I feel slightly disappointed in myself for buying this game under these circumstances, but it wasn't a complete waste (it has trading cards, too). It's been as cheap as US$ 1.24 (R$ 3,56) on Steam Store.

Verdict: Spectraball is another game I'd rate neutrally if I could, but I can't really recommend anyone to buy this. Some levels are very frustrating, the lack of checkpoints, the camera and all that, but you could still have some fun for a short while. So if you already have it, you might as well try it. If you don't have it, don't bother.

Similar games: Other games where you roll a ball across levels while solving puzzles are InFlux, and Lost Marbles. While I haven't played any of those yet, the latter seems more promising to me.

reviewText:
Spectraball is told to be a puzzle and platformer game. While the platformer part may be right, it is not a real puzzle game as thinking is not required. The so-called puzzles are way too linear and obvious to be a challenge and the only hard thing is beating your own timerecord, which shouldn't be the case for a puzzle game.
The graphics may have a rather good quality compared to other games of the genre, but there are a ton of useless and not good-looking shaders that make the game look even more unrealistic than it already is because of the platforms hanging free in the air (which is of course needed to qualify the game as a platformer, the devs may think) An example of the shaders that were put in the game without thinking can be seen in the screenshots: Every surface reflects the magic shine of the ball, may it be stone, dirt or snow.
The level-design is done very poorly and broken. The major problems include but are not limited to: Way too easy and boring parts, shadows hiding passages that don't seem to be meant as a secret passage (It would make no sense to hide it), and most importantly: About 50% of the obstacles are easy to overcome by just speeding towards them and then jumping all over the puzzle, skipping the complete part that would of course not have been a challenge otherwise.
The gameplay is way too short. I was able to complete the whole game in only 2 [Edit: 3] hours of gameplay. I did not try to be as fast as I can and instead tried to have fun with the whole world, but there are no extra parts or passages in it, only the straight obvious ways the player needs to take. I also played many levels multiple times because I got tired of this game when I first tried it and then decided to play it completely several months later.

I definetely do not recommend the game. Only 2 [Edit: 3] hours of gameplay are not worth the price and I did not enjoy any level of it and would not even have bought it if it was on sale for 20% of the full price if I knew that before.
I remember playing Ballance on my old computer, if anybody knows that. It is not as fast as Spectraball but sure has its similarities, being a true puzzling and platforming game. Why don't you have a look at that instead?

reviewText: Came into this hoping for a Super Monkey Ball-like experience, but unfortunately I didn't find it (nor have I found it in any game outside of Super Monkey Ball 1 or 2). It plays out more like a platformer where your character is a ball than a real...I'm not sure what you'd call it, but a game that focuses on the the physics, abilities, and limitations of the ball. The physics model of the game is lacking, level design feels uninspired, and there are many frustration points with long jumps back to checkpoints.  To top it all off it doesn't support controllers properly, only giving digital movement to the analog stick. Needless to say, that is the last nail in the coffin of a game in which your character is entirely round. Precision is important.

reviewText: The game preview misleads you to think you are going to be zipping by at Sonic speeds. You will actually be mostly crawling through the levels at a slow Marble Madness pace. Control over the ball also feels very loose and is easy to fall off the ledge on simple turns and narrow paths. The loose control also makes necessary speed and jump markers easy to miss. Small sections of the level will need to be attempted many times before a successful run. Personally, I would have had much more patience for this in the 80's and early 90's, but now I find the frustration level too great for mediocre entertainment.\n\nOn a side note, my system specs crush this game's requirements but still causes a complete system crash within 15 minutes or so. This too adds to my frustration with the game.

reviewText:
Ready to roll?

Spectraball is a platforming game that has both challenging puzzles, and an appealing art style. I got the game because I got 50% off with the coupon for completing a badge, and I must say it is pretty addicting for $3. You play as a ball and the goal is to get to the end of the level through a series of platforming and puzzle solving. The camera control is pretty spot on when you are playing, and each level introduces a new map mechanic that can make the game more challenging. The game has a few bugs which are pretty minor, nothing huge. However, one of the bugs I feel must be said is when you die the camera flips around to where you are supposed to go. So for example if you get to a checkpoint and the correct way is north, when you die and spawn you will be facing south.

All in all I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys platforming and puzzle solving.

A Marble game with basic rolling, jumping, and a selection of 3 powerups, where you have to go to the goal, solving certain puzzles and perform stunts.  The simplicity in the controls is not at all a problem here, but instead there's a sever lack of polish.

reviewText:
The physics work well, and the puzzles are good. I have just a few gripes with the game:

1. Checkpoints aren't placed in spots where they absolutely should be placed. This leads to replaying easy areas that lead into trickier areas, sometimes over and over to the point of annoyance.

2. The camera has some wonkiness (which is actually poor level set up) and leads to situations where you can't see the ball. This is less of an issue than #1, but from time to time, it's still annoying.

3. You can easily screw up on loops by pressing in the wrong direction (which is actually the direction you start the loop on). In most games that change your direction while moving, the movement continues in the direction of momentum as long as you keep the movement button pressed in the same direction you started with, which is what they should have done here.

4. Level size is much larger than one would expect starting even from the first level. Smaller levels up front, longer levels as you progress should be how it goes.

Overall though, a decent game. I would prefer if this was more of an RPG, as the levels are long enough to support some kind of progression for the ball (more speed, better control, etc.).

reviewText:
Before I get to the game, I should point out that I play on Mac only, but due to the poor coding of the game some of the content (like achievements and online leaderboards) won't work natively despite the game clearly being advertised for all platforms. Because of this I have to run the game through a Windows environment. When I have to emulate the game on a platform I'm not normally supposed to play in, that's a not a good sign.

I will give the game credit for its appealing visuals and super cool marble skins, but for the gameplay itself? It's highly lackluster and in some cases poorly made. The marble you control is slippery as all can be; trying to maintain your footing on platforms is a jarring task itself because of how bad the marble controls. There's also a severe lack of control when the marble is in mid-air too. 50% of the time when I'm trying to move while in mid-air the marble is just stuck almost in a straight, vertical line, and I end up undershooting a ton of jumps. The final unlockable you get in the game is a double jump for use with the power-up button. This should have been selectable by default because without this ability the level exploring is atrocious and ultimately an unpleasant experience. This game could have been something really impressive if they took more time to fine-tune the controls, make the acceleration less slippery, and overall make the movement more fluent. I would dare say this game is enjoyable only after you've gotten perfectly used to the awful controls, which is not good.

Apart from the main 7 levels (yes, there are only 7 levels in the game) are 3 different mini-games you can play. Arena is a poor-man's survival game where you can hug the center chain and last hundreds of seconds before the enemy marbles knock you off, Laser Jump is a basic jump-rope game with no real strategy to it, and Crate Chaos is an abysmal air-time" game that is infuriating to try and last 100 seconds on due to the aforementioned poor jumping controls. One cool feature I will admit adds more replay value and is somewhat enjoyable is the addition of a custom levels archive
date: which can be downloaded in individual sets for more action. They're shorter and surprisingly better designed despite most of them not being as aesthetically pleasing to the eye. As of this review
recommended: it's the only portion of this game that is bringing me back to play it from time to time.\n\nOverall I found this game to be a disappointing experience. Poor Macintosh compatibility despite clearly being advertised on all platforms

votesTotal: even if you are an avid marble platformer game fan. I recommend playing something like Lost Marbles

reviewText:
Spectraball is as simple as it is enjoyable.
It's easy to learn, easy to master, and easy to complete. It's well suited for any age group and skill level and can be mastered in a single sitting.
Spectraball offers no backstory and will only take two or three hours per playthrough. It presents a relaxing, ethereal soundtrack and pleasing scenery which create a relaxed, calming atmosphere.

I enjoyed spectraball, found it mostly worth its price, and will play it again in the future.

reviewText:
3D Platformers. They are a game genre that is rarely found anymore on the PC. Spectraball shows us what a classic video game should look like. A small character (or in this case a ball) jumping from platform to platform in original videogame locations like, a lavaworld, a snowland, a tropical island, a space station, and a desert world. The graphics are actually really well done for an Indie game and I haven't noticed any drop in framerate during gameplay. The sound is good, with an excellent soundtrack to follow. The controls work great and the difficulty level is pretty gradual. My only complaint is that the difficulty spikes to high degree on the second level. All in all a great game. Eaisily worth the 5 bucks!

Overall Rating: 9/10

Presentation: 9/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 7/10
Sound: 10/10
Difficulty: 6/10
Lasting Appeal: 6/10

Overall Rating: 9/10

Content Review:

Spectraball is an amazing game in terms of content. With absolutely no violence, language, or sexual content, this game is easily a game everyone should try.

Positive Elements: The game has a very uplifting and positive mood. Every location you visit is presented in a exciting and adventurous way.

0/10 (None) Violence: Your ball will sometimes fall into a pit or pool of lava but always immediately respawns without any violent explanation or death animation.

0/10 (None) Language: :)

0/10 (None) Sexual Content: :)

0/10 (None) Drugs/Alcohol: :)

0/10 (None) Negative Elements: :)

Final Content Rating: 10/10 (100% Clean)

reviewText: In Spectraball the protaganist is a ball that looks like it was pulled from the Tron universe and placed in a world of unmatched beauty. The world is full of ramps, loops, and go faster arrows that turn the ball into a speeding fireball traveling at ludicrous speed. I can't think of a better world for a ball to call home. I don't advise playing this while highly intoxicated. It will only frustrate you and put you on the path to rage. Stick to standard domestics with ABV 5% or less.

reviewText:
So Close...

This game has a lot going for it, its got pretty decent controls and a solid foundation to work on thats been used by many other 'Marble' type games. It however screws up totally when it comes to actual level design, its just not good. Why? Too many reasons to count and several of them even contradict each other.

Firstly: Some levels are just plain too confusing, you can often find yourself in certain areas with no clear idea on where to go or what to do. You then however get levels which are too SIMPLE and are finished off in a flash (and with the low level count as it is, this is very much a bad thing).

Secondly: None of the levels are memorable in any way, most consisting of a very basic theme and long stretches of dull lifeless jumping puzzles. The long levels really suffer for this (such as the Egypt level) where you can be bored still moving through it and then suddenly angered by the other two issues.

One of these issues being the small 'Rage' points in the game which just seem designed to be mean, balancing plinths that dont behave the same way, wind blasts that have little indication and the occasional 'Faith Jump' where you cant even make out where you are supposed to be landing.

The last issue is when you hit one of the many glitches and bugs. These are through the game and damage and already damaged product. I have gotten stuck in rocks, behind areas I wasnt supposed to be, in the floor at one point. I even managed to somehow get the achievement for the 'Balance' minigame by just staying still and getting trapped by all the other balls that were being shunted into the playspace, said balls didnt move the plinth at all.

Basically just leave it alone.

reviewText: Spectraball is part of a very narrow subgenre which you may call “ball platformers” (they are also called marble rollers"). These type of games usually are nothing more than glorified tech demos that showcase and engine’s graphical and physics capabilities.\nIn this regard
date: Spectraball is no different. You control a ball
recommended: have three possible unique powers to help you on the stages
hoursPlayed: and your goal is to try to reach the end of each stage as fast as possible.\n\nAlthough the game says it has puzzle elements
voteText: in reality this is a pure old-school platformer on par of the most well-known ball-busting hard NES titles from decades before.\nThis also means Spectraball is an excellent game for those who like to speedrun platformers
helpfulPercent: especially since the game has online leaderboards.\nSadly
votesTotal: with only seven stages and three survival challenge maps which each offer an achievement.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: if you like challenging platformers and indie engines which utilise wonderful graphics
commentsCount: this game is for you. If you want a puzzle game though
column16: you will more than likely be disappointed. If I had to add some numeric value to this review
column17: I'd go around 60/100; the game doesn't really have many strong or weak points
column18: it's just another indie platformer. A fun pasttime for a few bucks."

reviewText:
This was possibly the best $1.25 that I have ever spent. This game is a lot of fun and it has a lot of replayability. In addition to the seven maps in the main game, there are also many custom maps created by users that you can play through. My personal favorite level is the snow one. It is just a joy to play through.

In terms of gameplay, you basically roll a ball through beautiful and varied levels in order to reach an end goal and move on to the next. In addition to rolling, you are able to jump and use a power brake to instantly stop. Once you have beaten all the levels, you unlock ball designs inspired by each level and two new abilities you can use - teleport and double jump. There are timed leaderboards for each level and high scores for each of the minigames. Of the three minigames, the only one I returned to over and over was Crate Chaos because I was competing with someone for high scores.

I asked the person I played with if she wanted to add anything to this review and she said: This is a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome game. It is challenging without being too frustrating. I absolutely agree, but with that being said, I have to admit there were times when each of us rage quit out of frustration. That's the thing about this game - sometimes you might struggle with sections that seem ridiculously simple and other times you might breeze through them. There are absolutely challenging sections as well. There is an achievement for completing the seven main game maps in order without falling out once but I can't imagine ever dedicating the riduculous amount of time (and I'm going to say also luck) that it would take to accomplish that.

As for controls, I played throught this game once with the X-Box controller and once with the keyboard and mouse. What I found was that it was much easier to control my jump with the gamepad and easier to make tiny course adjustments with the keyboard/mouse. If you are struggling with one or the other, I suggest switching control schemes.

In short, this game was hours of fun for a very low price and it has the potential for tons of replayability. Especially if you were a beast at Marble Madness, you're probably going to want to check this out.

reviewText: Really can't say this game is for me.  I just didn't find it much fun.  It does have one of the most compelling villains ever to grace a game like this, or really a game like anything.  At first the camera seems like a helpful friend, somebody you can rely upon when you need it.  Then, betrayal!  And oh, what a betrayal.  From then on, the camera does everything it can to hinder you.  Putting track elements in your way when you're trying to navigate a tricky part, requiring an angle to position yourself that makes the route forward invisible.  That sort of back-stabbery.\n\nIn all honesty, I can't really say too much else is wrong with this game.  If you're into playing a platformer where you're a ball, similar to marble madness but without the rollerball control, then maybe this game is something you'd like.  But unless that is a very specific gameplay type that you really want to play, you'll probably have more fun with one of the many, many other games out there.

reviewText:
- A bad physics engine means that often the game thinks you happened to bounce a fraction of a milimeter, which means that very regularly, your acceleration is non-constant, and jumps don't register (so you miss the last critical jump in that series).
- Jumps (both from jump pads and the jump key) have a seemingly random height.
- No way to tell your speed or where you're about to land, so often you'll overshoot or undershoot a platform, without knowing until it's too late.
- Camera gets obscured by world objects that mean you don't see where you're going.
- Checkpoints in illogical places.
- Levels where it's actually possible to get stuck by losing a key prop, which doesn't get reset when you go back to a checkpoint, meaning you'll have to start over completely.
- No real puzzles, just really annoying tracks you have to get through.

Not recommended.

reviewText: This game isn't great or memorable, but there still are reasons I would recommend it. First, it has very nice and rich level design - there are several different kinds of environment. The game isn't boring or especially easy to beat. Controls are easy to get used to and various challenges you face in each level aren't repetitive (much). That being said, I need to mention several downsides. Spectraball can be frustrating - VERY frustrating. Sometimes, the ball just fails to jump, especially in dangling" platform parts of the game...and you want to smash the little ****. The last jump of the game is simply insane. I can't imagine how much time I would have to spend on Spectraball to get the most difficult achievment. Also
date: the game is fairly short. Despite the downsides
hoursPlayed: but rather if you find it on sale. If you like rolling ball games and are able to restrain yourself from smashing the keyboard

reviewText:
A simplistic marble platformer game, Spectraball is nothing if not inoffensive. The graphics are rather crude - while the actual ball itself looks nice enough, everything else in the levels looks like something from the PS2 era, with crude models and low-res textures being the rule rather than the exception. There was very little to excite in this game...

Yet, I don't really feel like it was a total waste of my time. It was reasonably challenging and it had okay levels. They were pretty ugly, but the actual platforming challenges in them were mostly fairly decent.

But on the whole the game was utterly unremarkable.

If you already own this game, playing it isn't a waste of your time, and it is a competent platformer. But don't expect anything more than that.

reviewText: After reading all the negative reviews, I went into Spectraball with low hopes that it would be a terrible marble game. EXPECTATIONS BLOWN AWAY. So much fun! One of my favorite games of all time is Marble Blast Ultra and THIS is so great maybe even better. Once you can get past the camera clipping issues and 'meh' level design in a few sections, you will have an absolute blast. The minigames that come packed in are a short little time waster, but the story mode is a lot of fun with quite a few levels, and the custom maps that people have made are insane! Highly recommend.\nGreat leaderboard intergration as well.

reviewText:
Grade: 92/100
Difficulty: Easy, intuitive controls -- yet challenging to execute in places.
Pros: Each level has a theme and those themes are lovely. Despite any failures, the game flow makes it easy to pick up where you left off and to improve on tricky spots until you succeed and make more progress. Most of the puzzles are challenging without being impossible, no matter how impossible they appear at first.
Cons: A little guidance to figure out what you're supposed to do in some spots would have been helpful.
Replayable: Absolutely. This is the fun sort of puzzle game that never gets old and is fun to show off to friends.

reviewText:
데굴!데굴!데굴!~ 가격도 싼데 쉽고 간단하게 즐길수 있는 점이 장점인 게임
공을 굴려서 목표 지점에 골인 시키면 되는 간단한 게임이다
여러 난이도가 있으며 한 난이도씩 클리어 해야 다음 난이도로 넘어갈수있다.
점프를 할수도 있고 순간정지도 할수있고 재미있게 만들어진 길을 따라서 가는점이 참 재미있다
간단히 재미있게 할 게임을 찾는 게이머라면 추천하는 게임이다.

reviewText: It's a bit of an older game, and its very simplistic. By today's standards it can feel unpolished, and there isnt any narrative or a story with it. But if you want a fun marble adventure based game, I'd say you can't go wrong for $5. It also has a few minigames that are a fun little way to kill time.

reviewText: Spectraball presents some fun and simple gameplay at first, but later devolves into confusing and often unituitive noob traps as the game progresses with some mind-numbingly pointless aspects, and relies on artificial difficulty. Far too many other games have similar potential for rewarding skill based puzzles but miss the mark by being weighed down from suffering with some of the most basic gameplay issues. Average at best.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/w6qoDus6R2g

It's a noble goal to want to make a game that embodies the best of 'Marble Madness' or 'Monkey Ball'.  However, 'Spectraball' fails to deliver on that promise.

Rough controls combined with a bland color pallet leads to uninteresting levels and numb gameplay.

reviewText: 4/5\nThe game was great for its short length. The physics were good, and the power break was really useful, even though it probably wasn't accurate in terms of real physics. The primary reason for not giving it a 5/5 was because some of the obsticles were irritating. For example, there was a TNT crate i had to jump onto get up somewhere. I don't know if it was the wall being too close or the crate being too weak, but i hand to use it 10-15 times before it finally got me high enough to proceed. Overall a good game you can beat in a day that has some nice minigames when you're done.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game, because I do not experience enjoyment from pounding nails through my genitalia and assorted other extremities. This game would be fine if the controls were more responsive or adaptive, but the controls and camera are bound to the same sensitivity slider. Want a responsive game? Then you had best be ready for a camera so fast it will induce nausea! Reasonable camera? Then no ball responsiveness for you!

Aside from that, the camera is really the worst part of this game; It clips through walls and blocks your view, so you are constanly battling with the view angles while also trying to avoid falling off-course. Whee?

There is a REASON this game has a :vein: emoticon! If you enjoy the game of labyrinth and like wasting HOURS trying over and over again, then by all means ignore my review and proceed onward, intrepid self-flagellist! Better yet, go find yourself the Lament Configuration puzzle box and have yourself a grand time! New dimensions of pain await you!

Ohhh, suffering... Good, VERY good!

reviewText: Nice little game. The playthrough time is really short but for example to me it took ages to get The Impossible achievement. Too bad devs didn't make more maps but luckily there are plenty of community maps avaible. There are also some minor bugs which appear now and then like speed boosts sometimes work randomly and ball might get stuck and you are not able to jump but those happen so seldom that it didn't really bother me at least.

reviewText:
This game honestly surprised me.

I got this game as a 66% off coupon on Steam, so I didn't think much of this game when I bought it, but I was quite surprised by how fun it was!

Let's move on to the pros.
-Fun and addictive
-The landscape's well thought out (For 2008)
-The physics weren't terrible
-Very enjoyable if you love a challenge
-Very challenging, especially on certain parts.

Cons:
-Extremely short
-The camera's not really the best
-Really bland custom levels and minigames
-Not really much to do after beating the game

I give this game a 7.5 out of 10 for taking a day's worth of my time. Thanks a lot!

reviewText:
Good game
+:
It's like the physics games with a ball in Mobile games, but with bigger levels and better graphics.
Interesting Levels and the music isn't bad or boring at all!

=:
it's not that puzzling, just figure out where to go and try not to fall. (at least the first 3 levels I encountered)

-:
It's tricky without a gamePad.
The camera goes many times inside the graphics instad of colliding with them and just rise up or down and you get to see the vast emptiness of the game. It's not appealing and also confusing sometimes during gamePlay.
It crashed one Time.
Sudden frame losses
